newsitem.title: USA: Pan Am buying Carnival Air, adding $60 million in financing.
newsitem.headline: Pan Am buying Carnival Air, adding $60 million in financing.

text.p: Pan American World Airways, a new company with a venerable name, announced a major expansion Friday, saying it would acquire Carnival Air Lines.
It also said it had arranged an additional $60 million in financing.

Pan Am Corp., which began operations last September with just two airliners, did not reveal financial terms of its agreement to acquire privately held Carnival Air, a regional airline with a fleet of 27 jet aircraft.
It said, however, that as part of the deal, Micky Arison, the majority owner of Carnival Air, would invest $30 million in the combined company, giving him a 42 percent stake.
Arison is chairman and chief executive of Carnival Corp., which operates Carnival Cruse Lines. But Carnival Air is not part of that company and is owned by Air Holding Corp.
Pan Am also said it had arranged a private placement of up to $30 million in a new series of convertible preferred stock.
Carnival Air, which was formed in 1988, has operations in South Florida, the Northeast, California and the Caribbean. It had about $270 million in revenues last year.

"The Carnival Air acquisition elevates Pan Am to a stronger competitive position and provides significant benefits of critical mass in an expedited, yet controlled manner," Pan Am President and Chief Executive Martin R. Shugrue Jr. said in a statement.
Last July Pan Am agreed to buy Carnival Air for about $100 million but called off the deal after PanAm examined the carrier's books and sought to rework the terms.

Pan Am currently has a fleet of four Airbus A300's -- with two more to be delivered in the next two months -- flying between New York and Los Angeles, New York and Miami, New York and San Juan, Peurto Rico, Miami and Chicago, and Miami and San Juan.
It plans to begin service between New York and Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, on April 6.

The original Pan Am, one of the world's first airlines, went out of business amid a myriad of problems related to competition, its limited route structure, industry deregulation and finally, the bombing of one of its airliners over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988.
Shugrue, who once headed the now-defunct Eastern Airlines, acquired the rights to the Pan Am name after the company went out of existence and later founded the new Pan Am, which is based in Miami.
Pan Am's stock fell 37.5 cents to $10.50 in early trading on the American Stock Exchange, where it was among the most-actively traded issues.
